comments.commentBody: I skipped the vegetable oil.  I skinned the thighs but did use bone in thighs.  I let it simmer, covered for 4 hours in step 4, until the meat was falling off the bones.  It made it more like a stew that I served over rice.  It isn't overly spicy.  It seemed different form the butter chicken that I have had before.  My kids liked it and so did I.

Southerners: Let's have a contest to design a new flag for the region. Take pride in your Southern heritage of hospitality, of respect for elders, of love of the land, of respect for religion. But slavery, though part of your history, is not "heritage." It is not the source of your values, not what holds you together. So a symbol that means slavery to so many people -- especially to those whose ancestors were slaves -- is not the appropriate way to express your regional loyalty.
I'll bet such a contest could produce something exciting that all Southerners, white and black alike, could respect and be proud of.
My friend made this for supper the other night.  It was so delicious.  Everyone at the table was exclaiming over the carrots!
Truth is the realm of the almighty.  The rest of us take facts (verifiable data anyone can look up) of varying credibility to arrive at a conclusion.
The state, the state, the state. You are the "state" my friend. We all are. It's not some alien creature.

While not matching conservative American views on welfare, it's hard to see a profound difference with groups such as the D.P.P.'s views on Islam and immigration. When you're talking 20 plus percent it isn't just a fringe presence anymore than the large number of Americans who view radical Islam and immigration as problems that need to be faced.
The biggest difference is the two party system that tends to require even the extreme elements left and right to be counted among the Democrats and Republicans. Multi-party systems allow these elements to maintain their identity however fringe they might be.
But here there are "fringe" groups who don't represent most conservatives but have a voice in the Republican party (an especially loud one in the primary season). Still, they aren't the voice of mainstream conservatives, though some might disagree.

I agree to some extent, but the root problems are different. Europe has I believe fared far better at integration of different races and cultures than the US. Historic minorities in both countries were inherited from different facets of colonialism, but whereas Europe avoided barriers to upward mobility through universal collective goods and services from education to healthcare to social safety nets that provide institutional "relief valves" in times of crisis (i.e. Wall St 2008 gift to the world), we tend to corral and protect our own looking the other way, discriminating in the provision of those basic goods and services.
There are breaking points on both sides of our western world, the rise of extreme rights on both sides of the pond are witness to this but the bottom line as most studies demonstrate today is yes the US produces more millionaires but has lost the lead in social mobility in favor of Europe.
"Financialization" of the systemic drive to monetize everything is one culprit, I will always remember Gordon Brown asking Angela Merkel how is it your economy prospers and her quip response "we still make things".

It is interesting that you write of Europe's faring "far better at integration of different races and cultures than the U.S." from a location in France, of all countries, Europe's poster child for multicultural tensions.  Accessible health care and education notwithstanding, the banlieus around Paris and other French cities paint a very different picture from the one you appear to be trying to paint.  I AM CHARLIE HEBDO.

Americans need from their media a lot more help understanding anti-immigrant and anti-Islam policies in far-right European populist parties.

Americans are misunderstanding that as if they were very different things that we have here. It isn't about the American fixations.

Americans fail to see some of what happens here on our fringes as signs that European problem is leaking over here. We need to understand that to recognize it here, and reject it here before it gets rolling.
Yes.  I see this young man's family, whoever gave him a gun that he was not legally entitled to, as an accomplice.  I do not understand why that person has not been arrested.

I agree.  This weekend someone questioned why, if the murderous intentions of radical Muslims (including those who are American citizens) are enough to make the Terrorism Task Force stop them before they kill, why aren't the murderous intentions of radical White Supremacists treated the same?  What's the difference?

This is an important observation. A duty to warn exists for professionals working with people who pose a threat. The government has not taken the same level of vigilance for terroristic threats that come from these white spremisist groups as they do for young men here in Minnesota who are being recruited by ISIS type groups. If working more closely with young Somali Americans who need support to avoid being misled by the recruiters of Islamic terrorist groups is working, it is time to recognize the same need in white youth being poisoned by hate/ terrorist groups of the white supremisist ilk.

I'm starting to wonder whether people who hear the Dylann Roofs of the world blurt out their demented plans to raise murderous havoc at schools and churches should be legally obligated to report such outbursts to the police.  Yes, freedom of speech is a right we all value but it's become increasingly clear that we can't simply dismiss the hate-filled rants of lunatics and assume they'll ultimately chill out.

I had these insights when I got my first dog.  He needed a lot of exercise and I took up running. And I can remember running past a health club that had a row of treadmills in the window and thinking how much more fun I was having being outside with my dog than they were running in place.  It made me feel so alive to navigate the elements, so much more agile for running on all different kinds of terrain.  At that point it's not about speed as much as being adaptable.  Mastering what's out there, what's unpredictable, rather than subjecting yourself to a bunch of monotonous machinery.

Wow!  I guess it doesn't matter that there have have Black Supreme Court Justices, Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense, Attorney Generals, and many others not to mention President of the United States all in a country that wants "to keep Black people rotgut poor forever".
April, they have access.  It is simply the get up and go to provide that accomplished access for themselves.  Giving it away is not a good idea.

It's actually easier to impose monopoly rents on users of telecom services, especially those for whom there is no alternative to the current oligopoly of providers.  Shallow sloganeering that has little to do with prevailing reality gets us nowhere.

It is always easy to pass entitlements by imposing taxes on others.  Unfortunately, politicians have the luxury of doling out other people's and other generation's money with no consequences.   As long as debt is cheap & they can keep adding to the $15T of national debt, they will keep giving away freebies.

Actually, Mr. Windley - there are a LOT of homes in rural areas that cannot get any Internet service other than $60/month for 5GB...with a $200 up front charge.  Not sure, but I think that 5GB is about ONE DVD-s worth of data.  Oh, and if you don't have access to true broadband, you may have serious challenges in acquiring the skills needed to get a job of 'legitimate work'.
Yeah, ten bucks is going to by a lot of bandwidth Bill.
Condescend a little, will you?
Great, now porn and internet gambling can steal more productivity, and actual money...from the poor.

Isn’t google’s new move setting up for dilemma? If one comes to share “deeply personal information” that includes a picture that they either gave to someone or willingly let them take, and it ends up on the web whose subjective view do we appropriate that this now needs to be removed?

This is not to condone revenge porn but what are we saying when we start claiming that speech can be illegal just because it is embarrassing …? Will google now also be asked to remove other material that I may petition because I find offensive or predatory?

http://scallywagandvagabond.com/2015/06/right-move-google-to-ban-revenge...
Because Google is a virtual monopoly.

The email I got about this article said, "If Google deems an image revenge porn, it will still be accessible to someone who knows the direct web address of the image. But once delisted from Google, the image could not be found through the search engine."  It's interesting that it's even a concern that someone wouldn't be able to access a site by entering its web address if Google doesn't have it in their search results anymore.  Google isn't in charge of the web.  Would people even think that's possible???
Google could also de-list torrent sites but instead gives them top listings since Google profits from selling ads on piracy sites.

If people were "toilet trained", this would not be necessary. When you want or need to look at your phone, remember it is your responsibility to stay out of the way of others.  Simply stop and place yourself in a quiet spot out of the flow of foot traffic.  Respect others and exercise common courtesy.  Too bad there isn't an app for that.

Didn't they already have those everywhere? Escalators in New York City, moving walkways at LAX, crosswalks in Chicago, etc?

And hey, if it happened in Orem, Utah, the idea surely is one that's time has come.

Hydrogen is a very small molecule, making it hard to keep hold of - it tends to escape wherever it is being held. The technology is basically an energy storage system, there are no significant sources of hydrogen - it must be generated using energy as you stated. My biggest fear is that natural gas (CH4) will be used as a cheaper way to generate hydrogen (H2) as there are 4 hydrogen atoms in a natural gas molecule. The carbon leftover is a pollutant.

Perhaps because she lacks the essential qualities possessed by both Lewis and Didion, beginning with genuine humility and ending with the suspicion that they did not have the final word in the matter.

I'm remembering all of the people that supported George Zimmerman, giving him money.

And I wonder how Zimmerman himself feels about this, being tied in with this terrorist.

Not that I really care; both of them are murderers. It's astounding that some of the jurors felt that George was a "nice boy" or words to that effect.

A final, personal note: here is a link to an email I received from Rev. Clementa Pinckney. I offer this email contact as a note of remembrance in the spirit of commemorating the qualities of humility, activism, openness, insight, and institution building Reverend Pinckney exhibited as he worked among us. God has blessed his work. [http://wp.me/p1mBVu-40K].

Also, I must admit I am unable to rise to the example of the greatest Christian witness this nation as ever seen: the family members of the nine murdered, their voices breaking in grief, one by one, declaring their forgiveness, to bring no hate to their loss as they honor those they loved. This is no doubt the most moving and magnificent example of divine strength and faith I will witness in my life time. I am blessed by their grace.

"Hardly an example of any good citizen" (with which I by every measure disagree!) don't deserve death at the hands of a person who the police specifically ordered to stand down. Zimmerman was ordered by dispatch not to pursue, violated that directive and engaged a teenager with skittles for no more reason or authority that his egomanical devotion to narcissistic looking glass of justice. His record of violent threats involving women since the killing, his freeway contact that resulted in a bullet hole in his truck window speaks to his on-going attraction to violence and guns.

Distort as you will the facts by a subjective reading, Zimmerman's behavior--not Martin's--put them both at risk, and the fact--fact!--remains his actions resulted in Mr. Martin's death. Moreover, I would be careful to "judge" a youngster you do not know from media accounts, who, even by those reports, did not engage in behavior out of the ordinary for youth, black and white. It sounds like "blaming the victim," which I am sure is not your intent. Is it?

Lastly, I deeply resent the use of "frenzy," and "primed" to describe the outcry to successive acts of murder and the raising of legitimate grievances. Honestly, I am more "enraged" by your comment and your willingness to "contort" murder into a misunderstanding, ignoring the very words and acts, pattern and practices that clearly establish these deaths as racial acts--administered and protected by institutional forces against communities of color.

I have long said denial and racism are a part of the same double helix. No doubt we will see the idea that skepticism is good Jesuit practice! Seriously, woven into America's racism is the fabric of denial, but looking beyond the standard practice of rhetoric, action, and the denial, several things are asunder. The killer says he was motivated by the Trayvon Martin case. but in that instance, the accused white man was acquitted! How does hate intensify with and acquittal? The killer lives near Columbia, South Carolina, why didn't he select one of that city's historic churches? What readings did he do from which white supremacy sites? Was he in contact with white supremacists? Where did he spend the night before he was apprehended?

The answers may or may not shed deeper insight into his motivation or whether he had help. What we know now, by his own words, his posted symbols and images, his manifesto from the dark web, his domain name, and his witness to victims he shot and let survive, and to the police, is that his is a standed template of racism supported by others with standards templates of denial. Racism exists, but because of denial, its acts can never be found!

Let's look for what can be found, directly or indirectly: did this young man have help and from where with his ideas or acts?

The purpose of denial is to distract from deeper examinations. Let's step beyond its entangling intent.
